The spin-dependence in Eqs.~(\ref{TBM}) and (\ref{gap}) assures the occurrence of spin nondegenerate TAI phases which results in mismatched conductance plateaus with values of $e^2/h$ and $2e^2/h$ as discussed for the clean case. By solving these two equations, we get TAI phase boundaries as shown in Fig. \ref{fig2}(e)-(h). Here the red (green) lines are for spin projection up (down). The vertical lines separate the topologically trivial region (left) and nontrivial region (right). The other horizontal lines encode the evolution of the effective conduction and valence band edges with disorder. Band inversion appears at the transition point. For modest disorder, this effective medium theory yields an adequate description of the TAI various phases in the $W-E_F$ plane.






{\it Local spin current.}---In order to confirm the statement that the quantized conductance plateaus in Figs. 2(e)-(h) are contributed by robust chiral edge states, we study the NLSC. In a two terminal setup, a $35a/\sqrt{3} \times 40a$ nanoribbon with zigzag edges is connected to source and drain electrodes. First, we focus on the QH phase confirming the existence of robust edge current under strong disorder. For $W=3t$ and $E_F=0.9t$ in the bulk band gap (see the red spot in Fig. \ref{fig2}(e)), the NLSCs are displayed in Fig. \ref{fig3}(a). Apparently, the NLSCs for both spin up and down currents are highly localized at the top edge. The same propagation direction of spin up and down indicates that the edge states are chiral and oppositely polarized. The NLSCs at the bottom edge are suppressed because the charge motion is directed against the source-drain bias voltage. Second, we consider the $e^2/h$ quantized conductance plateau in the QAH phase. For $W=3t$ and $E_F=0.5t$ in the valence band (see the red spot in Fig. \ref{fig2}(f)), the NLSCs are shown in Fig. \ref{fig3}(b), where the robust edge current is identified only for spin down. The NLSC for spin up is randomly oriented and does not cross the entire sample. Finally, in the trivial phase, the NLSCs in the $2e^2/h$ quantized conductance plateau with $W=4t$ and $E_F=0.6t$ (see the red spot in Fig. \ref{fig2}(g)) are shown in Fig. \ref{fig3}(c). As expected, robust edge currents for both spin up and down projections are readily visible.


{\it Summary.}---In this work we introduce and study a model that exhibits a couple of novel TAI phases with opposite-spin and single-spin polarized chiral edge states. These TPs are distinct from the ones encountered in the HgTe quantum well \cite{TAI1}. The quantized conductance plateaus at $e^2/h$ and $2e^2/h$ associated with QH, QAH and trivial phases are displayed and analyzed in the $W-E_F$ plane. Transition between these two TAI phases results in a conductance jump $e^2/h \to 2 e^2/h$. Within the self-consistent Born approximation, we demonstrate how disorder drives these TP transitions. Thus, for moderate disorder we achieve a complete description of TAI phases in the $W-E_F$ plane. In addition, calculation of NLSC substantiates the picture that the quantized conductance in TAI phases is contributed by robust chiral edge states.\\
